Award.AwardTitle: Designing Novel Types of Cooperative Effects to Influence Catalytic Performance

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study seeks to design a solid-catalyst substitute for a liquid-phase catalytic process used to convert fructose (obtained from biorenewable sources) to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) - a key intermediate chemical that can be further processed to a range of fuel and chemical products. The solid-catalyst approach has the potential to reduce the cost and complexity of biorenewables processing, thereby making bio-fuels and bio-chemicals more competitive with fossil-derived analogs. The study will also include an educational outreach plan that will increase the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM fields.

Specifically, the PI seeks to co-immobilize the two elements of the conventional liquid-phase process (sulfonic acids in a dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) solvent) on a solid silica support to achieve cooperative catalytic sites that dehydrate fructose to HMF with high selectivity. The proposed work will focus on the precise grafting of organosilane tethering agents onto the silica support to achieve the desired cooperative effects. Optimization will be achieved by varying several properties of the tethered groups such as length and molecular structure. The study will also address the stability of the tethered species in the aqueous reaction environment. The technological impact of the project can be substantial if it can open the door to a water-based process that eliminates the energy intensive (and expensive) distillation process currently needed to separate the product HMF from the DMSO solvent. Overall, this would create a more direct route from biomass to HMF - a versatile platform chemical that can be used to create biomass-derived polymers, to synthesize fuel additives, or to produce commodity chemicals from renewable sources. In addition to undergraduate and graduate education opportunities, the project will interface with several existing programs at Ohio State University to create a classroom module for students and a project to introduce the concepts of acids and bases to elementary school children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research has investigated the design of new catalytic materials for the selective conversion of biomass to valuable chemicals. The discoveries have included new catalytic materials for two important chemical reactions including the conversion of glucose to fructose and dehydration of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), widely considered the most valuable biomass derived products.  These results have been broadly shared through a combination of publications, presentations, and community outreach activities organized by the group, including incorporating the outcomes of the research into classroom discussions and assignments.

The specific research advancements include discoveries about the catalyst structure that impacted the overall performance. For dehydration of fructose to HMF, it has been reported that dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) promotes the conversion of fructose and yield of HMF, but it is speculated that DMSO decomposes to acid species. A range of experimental work was used to demonstrate that DMSO does not degrade to acidic species under reaction conditions. This creates the possibility of designing a catalyst that has a sulfoxide containing polymer. The sulfoxide polymer helped to increase the rate of fructose conversion and to improve the yield of HMF. The design of the catalyst played a crucial role, requiring balancing the quantity of sulfoxide groups to achieve high HMF selectivity while allowing catalyst accessibility. Overall, the tuned design could be used to achieve high HMF selectivity while using favorable environmentally friendly solvents.

 For glucose isomerization, it was identified that the molecular structure of the catalyst affected the overall performance. Through modifying both the structure of the catalytic site, the catalyst activity could be increased by over an order of magnitude. Additional novel heterogeneous catalyst consisting of nanotubes were demonstrated to be selective for fructose when converting glucose. 

 Combined, these studies provided new insights on the design of heterogeneous catalysts for biomass conversion. The work has the potential to broadly impact the design of future heterogenous catalysts for biomass conversion as well as pharmaceutical production. These important implications have and will continue to be shared broadly to inspire future generations to create sustainable materials for upgrading biomass.
